description:
Artibeus intermedius, commonly known as the intermediate fruit-eating bat, is a species of bat belonging to the family Phyllostomidae. It is found in Mexico and Central America, from southern Mexico to Panama.

The Artibeus intermedius is a medium-sized bat, with a wingspan of approximately 60-70 cm. It has a rounded face, large eyes, and large ears. The fur is short and soft, with a grayish-brown coloration on the back and a lighter, greyish-white coloration on the underside.

These bats are primarily frugivorous, feeding on a variety of fruits, including figs, bananas, and other tropical fruits. They play an important role in the ecosystem by dispersing seeds and pollinating plants.

Artibeus intermedius is known to roost in a variety of habitats, including caves, hollow trees, and man-made structures, such as buildings and bridges. They are typically found in tropical and subtropical forests, as well as in urban and agricultural areas.

The conservation status of Artibeus intermedius is classified as "Least Concern" by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), as the species is widespread and relatively common throughout its range.
